subject: Re: TestUtil: By Example
msgSnippet: ... would need a ... (@NonNull) but ... is the added ... -- Begin MT TestUtil can interrogate every method in the code base and provide summary data regarding
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Mark Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:
>
> > It's sometimes okay for methods to receive null arguments. You
would need a
> > way to differentiate methods that need a non-null parameter
(@NonNull) but
> > even so, the method is probably going to throw an NPE, so where
is the added
> > value?

-->Begin MT
TestUtil can interrogate every method in the code base and provide
summary data regarding the behavior of those methods in a testing
context. A person responsible for the overall health of the code
base can determine if the behavior(s) are consistent with the
application development team design patterns.

As mentioned, methods with unique behavior require special
handling. Mark had the idea of using JavaDoc to communicate special
handling requirements to the TestUtil verifier.
-->End MT

>
> In our current architecture - we say that a method should either
> accept Null, an EmptyString, etc. as a valid input or it should
throw
> an ArgumentException (AE). So in our world view a NPE indicates a
> coding error inside the API. I like the distinction an AE says that
> the API is not being used correctly whereas a NPE says the API is
> broken.
>
> Ron Jefferies thinks this approach is dead wrong and that methods
> should just do the right thing with Null's etc. I just don't see
what
> the right thing is most of these cases.
>
> So my suggestion was pass in Null, emptyString, etc. to methods
(not
> restricted to tests). If they either threw an AE or didn't throw
> anything then they would be deemed to have passed. It would
indicate
> that the developer had considered what to do with Null's et al.

-->Begin MT
The notion of Verification Facilitator includes the following
comment from TestUtil: By Example:

"It is becoming apparent to the author the use of Verification
Facilitators relies heavily on a strong shared understanding and
consistent coding practice for a core patterned object (DAO,
Business Object, Application Service Object etc.)."

A DAO method may have a different contract for handling of nulls
than a BO or an ASO. The Verification Facilitator must
be "patterned object" aware - and flag contract violations
accordingly.
-->End MT

>
> The hard part is dealing with methods that have multiple
parameters.
> For any method that has more than one object as a parameter, you
have
> to be able to create an instance of those objects - so that you're
> tests only test one parameter at a time.

-->Begin MT
The heavy-lifting is completed with the current version of
TestUtil. Multiple parameter (argument) objects are recursively
instantiated as required.
-->End MT
